meeting_annotations.speaker: Alice Soragni
meeting_annotations.transcript: all I can think about is organoids. I think to me a reductionist approach when you take things out and make them again ex vivo and then produce something that looks like where you came from and it's functionally equivalent is a good way to define a unit. So complexity is great, but there are other ways to make it easy and digestible, I guess.
meeting_annotations.other: Erika Matunis gives a thumbs-up gesture at 00:24.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Neil Kelleher
meeting_annotations.transcript: When you make organoids, do they try to form something like the structures of the organ?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erika Matunis JHMI
meeting_annotations.transcript: Absolutely.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Alice Soragni
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erika Matunis JHMI
meeting_annotations.transcript: Pretty much.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Alice Soragni
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, they are fantastic models out there for pretty much any organ you can think of. So we do disease, so I'm not a normal organ person, but there are models for anything and everything you can think of. And they secrete the same, they signal the same, they beat, they produce waves if you're doing brain, I mean they do all sort of things.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erika Matunis JHMI
meeting_annotations.transcript: They make really pretty realistic looking embryos.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Alice Soragni
meeting_annotations.transcript: That's yes, also.
meeting_annotations.other: She smiles and laughs while responding.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erika Matunis JHMI
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay, so are you guys able to see all of our beautiful notes so far? We've been talking quite a bit about our defining these neighborhoods.
meeting_annotations.other: She appears to be referring to a shared document that is not visible on screen.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Neil Kelleher
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah we could maybe go to another question.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erika Matunis JHMI
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yes, I think we should definitely. So the next question is asking about leveraging better imaging or newer imaging modalities. And I think we have people to do that here. So can anyone who does imaging or would like to talk about imaging give us some thoughts on applying imaging to these tissue cell interaction questions?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Lulu Cambronne, UT Austin
meeting_annotations.transcript: It's really hard.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Neil Kelleher
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I agree.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erika Matunis JHMI
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah. Ross, what do you think about it?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ross Wang, Temple U
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think it's pretty challenging. I think it's relatively easier now in terms of imaging of fluorescence-based imaging. It's easier to define the cell type and people can use an antibody against different biomarkers belonging to the CD series on the cell membrane. But then it's very difficult to trace the messenger molecules to understand cell-cell interaction. And my colleagues are using even having to give up whole fluorescence-based imaging, but instead using PET, the PET imaging in vivo in order to track certain like T-cell subunits. And especially for messenger molecules such as lipids and others that cells use to interact, those are very, you need I think certain more ultra-sensitive technology is needed here. In other words, there could be a lack of tool available.
meeting_annotations.other: He has a whiteboard with chemical structures and equations behind him.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erika Matunis JHMI
meeting_annotations.transcript: So what kind of tool would be your dream new tool to help study this?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ross Wang, Temple U
meeting_annotations.transcript: Well ideally some probes that offers extreme sensitive but also I will say in terms of the time, there's no relapse. So there's a certain delay, there's also issue about the probe detection. When you design a probe to detect those messenger molecules, sometimes based on the activity, and then there's also a delay about, you know, seconds to minutes between the signal on and the real molecule is already there.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erika Matunis JHMI
meeting_annotations.transcript: So something really fast.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ross Wang, Temple U
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, and rapid and sensitive way.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erika Matunis JHMI
meeting_annotations.transcript: Does anybody else have ideas about tools?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Tania Lupoli, NYU
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I feel like you'd want something that promotes specificity, right, between cell types. I mean I'm thinking of host-pathogen. So if you had a a probe that only reacted with like a bacterial enzyme, right, in a in a host environment, that would give you specificity. And I think the best lipid probes have been, you know, lipids that are particular to a cell type.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Wenjing Wang, UMich
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think, yeah, this is really challenging also because like, so if we want high spatial resolution, which nowadays can only be achieved using fluorescence probe, but then fluorescence molecules are like very challenging in these big tissues and organisms. And then luminescence, but then luminescence, the spatial resolution is kind of poor. You can engineer sensors for detecting specific molecules, but then you sacrifice the spatial resolution. Same with like PET or MRI, I guess. MRI can be pretty fast, but then also like spatial resolution. So I guess ideally is that if people can engineer the next generation MRI or PET and then with different mechanism and can achieve that much better spatial resolution and also, I know there are now people engineering MRI probes that can also be used to recognize specific kind of enzymes or molecules, and those can give very good temporal resolution, so spatial resolution it can be cracked down. So maybe eventually one day we really can be able to look at in these live organisms and to look at these signaling events. But I don't know how long that would take.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erika Matunis JHMI
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yes, I always go to seminars that advertise that and usually since I've worked on cells and I really want to see inside the cells, I'm still been a little bit disappointed, but it would be wonderful if there would be advances in that area. Does anyone else have ideas about how to better see into tissues?

meeting_annotations.speaker: GW Gant Luxton UC Davis
meeting_annotations.transcript: I was just I was just going to say, you know, maybe we don't need the latest and greatest new imaging tool. We can actually go back a little bit and look at things like viral tracing, right? Where you can map which cells in the brain are talking to which cells by trans-synaptically traveling viruses like pseudorabies virus, for example. And I'm wondering if since microbes, you know, Tania really reminded me, after studying viruses as a grad student, they are the original cell biologists, right? So why not let them do what they're good at and illuminate functional units.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Neil Kelleher
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, the clash of like reductionist, I want to measure as many molecular components in space and time as possible and then this counter that we've heard a couple times in this discussion about, hey, let's have a more biologically inspired method to define function. Um, and yeah, so it's an interesting or just non-molecular imaging. Like PET was mentioned, you just mentioned one that's like a it's it's lower, you can get enough information about a biological system through other images and if we just applied the resources there, you know. So I don't know, it's probably it's going to be a little bit of A and B here, but um, but I think within our decade here, we are going to have a very different operational paradigm about how to connect phenotype with molecular work. And I feel like it's a major challenge to become aware of that and and like Erika said, leverage it. Um, so I I love this discussion to try to just elevate my own competitiveness, competitive fitness.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Tania Lupoli, NYU
meeting_annotations.transcript: I had a quick question for something Wenjing said about luminescence. Do you think it lacks spatial resolution even if you, you know, only express luciferase in certain places that and that luciferase is orthogonal to a particular substrate?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Wenjing Wang, UMich
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, that yeah, Tania, actually that's a great point. So I guess spatial resolution, so when you do the imaging, you are just going to see a blob in maybe a tissue. So you don't get much spatial resolution that way. But yes, if you specifically express them in specific regions, so you just looking at whether it happens or not, but your space but already these genetic encoded tools are like spatially defined before, then then I guess you can still use that to monitor the events in specific locations that you put the genetic codes to.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Tania Lupoli, NYU
meeting_annotations.transcript: Got it, yeah.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erika Matunis JHMI
meeting_annotations.transcript: So you're saying you can only see what you were looking for?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Wenjing Wang, UMich
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, that's true. So it's the answer yes or no question, I guess.
meeting_annotations.other: Both she and Erika laugh at the end of the exchange.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erika Matunis JHMI
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Alice Soragni
meeting_annotations.transcript: And maybe I can add something we started doing implementing recently, which I think it's really cool. Of course I'm biased, you know, obviously. But we started implementing live cell interferometry, which is a way to see how heavy the things or how is mass moving within your cell or within your organoid. And it's label-free and it's non-invasive and you can do that all the time. You're just measuring the weight of things on the basis of the light going through. And so there are ways, of course, you know, you don't get, you can still get within cell information to some extent. You cannot get sub-organelle information, but we are seeing that it's very interesting how cells move things around.
